updates.update_content:
Hi Everyone,
Thank you
I just wanted to touch base and thank each of you one last time for believing in this project and buying a book. Watching this book get made, printed, and shipped out has been one of the most stressful, but overall rewarding projects of my career. I'm really proud of SkyHeart and happy to have finished it.

Books are Here!
The books arrived safe and sound from my printer in China. So relieved!

Exciting news! The books are on a boat headed to Provo and get here September 14th.
The printer overnighted a couple of books so I could see what they look like. They turned out so good. Better than I had expected! 
Here's some photos:

I got the proofs back from the printer and the book is looking great!
I'll admit that when I delivered the files to the printer I was SO DONE. I didn't want to think about SkyHeart. But now, seeing these pages, leafing through them with my fingers, it's making me want to drop everything and start book 2!
I'm wrapping up the loose ends with SkyHeart before I send it off to the printers. This week I finished the cover!

You guys, YOU GUYS! Interior pages of SkyHeart are FINISHED!
This includes all the coloring, lettering, copy editing, formatting, back matter, title pages, chapter breaks, copyright page, and end pages. The book is built out in InDesign and ready to export. 
The last thing on my list is designing and polishing the front and back cover.

Before the month closes out I wanted to share with you some colored pages. As of right now I have 94 pages colored, 32 left to do.
Here's some of my favorites so far:
Inks are finished!

Just wanted to wrap up the year with another SkyHeart update.
Ater squeezing in as much drawing as I could in between everything this month I was able to get half of the pages done in this 5th and final chapter of SkyHeart.
You can see some of these pages here. Because of all the detail they took FOREVER.

Hello Everyone!
Touching base here at the end of November to let you know where things are at.
Finished with layouts on Chapter 5. You can see those here below. (Don't look too close if you want to avoid any spoilers.) Chapter 5 ended up being 6 pages longer than all the other chapters. Just couldn't fit everything I wanted to write into 24 pages.

campaign.story:
We hit the goal!  Shiver Bureau will be printed.  But lets see what other fun stuff we can add in the remaining time.
I will add all the original stories I created when I was first conceiving Shiver Bureau.  Fully illustrated covers and sequential pages.  I think this will be at least 20 extras pages of content.  This will be awesome to have in the book just for the sure zaniness of the stories, but it will show the Shiver Bureau in its infancy.  The story, the characters and even me grew a lot in the 8 years it too to get to this point.  I think these pages will really showcase that growth.
Prints of cool interior pages, panels and the cover will be sent out with all physical shipments.
All books will be printed in glorious hardcover!
The hardcover will be upgraded to include some tasteful embossing.  My plan is to emboss the logo, Trish, and Pickle.  Also I will start compiling a massive concept art book for Shiver Bureau volume 2.  All backers who gave $10+ will get a digital PDF copy of this book when complete.
Upgrade Level twooooooo! The book will get a spot UV treatment.  I think that is something like a spa day for graphic novels.  I want to add a shiny, 'invisible' ghost to the back cover.   A spooky friend you only spot out of the corner of eye when the hair raises on the back of your neck.
Shiver Bureau: Welcome to London is a 150 page graphic novel.  That's 150 pages of full on story.  There will be some bonus content in the back as well. It will be a paperback unless we raise enough to afford a hardcover.
Best part is, this first volume is completely finished.  I'm not waiting for the artist to art, or the colorist to color, or the letterer to letter, or even the snozzleblurrer to snozzleblur.  I just need cash money to get it printed.
Suitable for all ages with parental guidance.  There is some cartoon violence and monsters lurking about.  But nothing worse then a Saturday morning cartoon.
This is the first volume of a trilogy (possibly a quadrology) but this volume is self contained and serves as an introduction to the world, characters, and the awesome.
It's also a webcomic that you can read for free at http://shiverbureau.com/
The world is overrun with ghosts and it's up to the Shiver Bureau to keep things under control. But everything isn't as it seems, the bureau is corrupt and there are things lurking in the shadows that are far worse then the shivers.
That's where Pickle, Trish, Mr. Todd and Oliver come in.  The is Pickle's first day in London and already he's been attacked by shivers, fallen out of a blimp and been shown up by his assistant*.  How much worse could his day get?  A lot worse...Welcome to London.
Pickle is taking over the London headquarters.  Not only does he have to deal with shivers, but he needs to clean up the bureau, deal with a power hungry minister, get back his assistant*, and there are rumors about missing kids.  I think Pickle needs a vacation (wink wink volume 2 wink nod wink wink wink wink...sorry got something in my eye).
There are a wide assortment of characters, but the main dogooders are...
Pickle is an Inspectre, a rare type of person with the ability to lay shivers to rest.  He is overly confident, but has the skills and the mouth to back it up...most of the time.  Pickle thinks he's the hero of the story...
Luckily, Trish is there to remind him that he's not.  Trish is the power house of the group.  She's not just a brute though, she has more than enough smarts to keep Pickle and his mouth in check. *Not Pickle's assistant.
Mr. Todd fixes everything that Trish and Pickle break.  He also makes some really cool toys.  Don't let his size fool you, he's no good in a fight...he's a pacifist and very huggable.
Oliver is the next generation.  He embodies the best of Pickle, Trish, and Mr. Todd. Maybe some of their faults as well.  When he's older, he will be someone to reckon with...if he can live that long.
Well I'm me, silly...
More info?  Okay, my name is Walter Ostlie and I am a part-time storyteller who dreams of retiring early to create new worlds and new possibilities, to boldly go where no cartoonist has gone before...or go where they went but put my own twist on it.
Shiver Bureau is my second graphic novel.  My first is Cubicles: The Movie: The Graphic Novel...or just call it Cubicles.  It's a sci-fi comedy about two office workers who get dragged across the universe.  It's pretty funny, you should read it.  It's available on Comixology.  You can read the first chapter for free and the entire novel is only 4 bucks.  That's like 80 pages of hah hah hilarious uproar for 4 bucks. What?  What!
https://www.comixology.com/Cubicles/comics-series/6589
$10 - Not only do you get a digital copy of the story, but also some overloaded bonus content.  You will get the B/W, unlettered version of every page plus all the bonus content I can wrangle up.
$25 - Get the fresh off the presses print edition of Shiver Bureau plus the oversized PDF and a Shiver Bureau bookmark.
$35 - Get a snazzy original ink sketch on the inside of your new print copy of Shiver Bureau plus you get all the cool stuff from the previous tier.
$60 - Get this fashionable Shiver Bureau t-shirt.  Not only is it styling and profiling, but it's functional.  No shirt, no service.  Any pledge 60+ will have their name printed in the 'Thank You' section of the book.

You pick any character you want and I'll draw them looking their coolest.  Keep it to a single character.  Background are at my discretion.  You also get the signed print copy and overloaded PDF.
$90 - This is like the $35 tier but even cooler. Instead of sketching in the Shiver Bureau book, I will sketch on a separate 6" x 8" card stock. You pick any character you want and I'll draw them looking their coolest. Keep it to a single character. Background are at my discretion. You also get the spooky shirt, signed print copy and overloaded PDF.

$400 - Do you want something drawn, need someone to draw it, why not commission me?  Get an original 11x17 ink wash commission by me...the tortured artist mentioned above.  Instead of the commission you could choose one of my already completed original illustrations.  Plus all the other goodies.  See all the available original art pieces at the bottom of this update here.
$600 - The one, the only original art for the cover of Shiver Bureau volume 1.  This is the thing you want.  Plus all the other goodies, obviously.

updates.update_content: Just wanted to let you know about a new project I am working on.  It's the second volume of Is'nana The Were-Spider.  It is on Kickstarter now and already reached it's main goal of 12,000 dollars.  Now it's headed towards the stretch goal of 16,000 and that's when I show up.  If the project can hit the goal, than I will be drawing and coloring a 40 page backup story for the book.  That means the book you get will have an extra 40 pages and you won't have to pay more.  40 free pages, what?!?!

Great news.  The books are printed and they look amazing!
Picking a printer and working through all the printing issues was way more work then I thought it would be.  There is a lot of stress involved when you have to make 2000 copies of one thing.
However, now that I see them, all of them, and see how dope they look, it makes it all worth it.  I can't wait to get these books in my hands.  I may have to lay them flat and lay my mattress on top of them because there are so many but it will be totally worth it.

Here is the "Thank You" page.  I copied and pasted directly from Kickstarter so all names should be correct, but if you see something wrong just let me know.  Originally it was only supposed to be for $60+ backers, but I included everyone since we all did this together.  It seemed right.  However, to be fair to the $60+ backers, their names are larger.
Thank you!

campaign.story:
STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT is a documentary series featuring human stories about real people whose lives have been changed by video games. Some of them make games. Some of them play games. All of them are helping make the video game community one of the most vibrant and exciting collections of humans on Earth.
I made this video with Christian Cicerone over four days of shooting and five days of editing. Imagine what we could do with your backing and support!
I can't wait to show you what these people are really like, what drives them and how they do what they do.
We've begun production on the following two episodes:
Episode 01: FOX, BIRD, BEAR. Spry Fox just released the clever word game "Alphabear". Before that, its "Triple Town" made waves (and attracted controversy). With less than a dozen developers working form all over the world, this mid-sized indie studio is trying to turn modest successes into long term survival. Their next game, "Steambirds" could be the breakout they need. 
Episode 02: FAMILY BUSINESS. John Romero created "Doom". Brenda Romero has worked for decades as a game developer. Now they're working with young Donovan on "Gunman Taco Truck" and helping others learn the joy of game making. This is the story of the Romero's "Family Business".
Additional episodes will include the stories of:
  And if we're funded to our second stretch goal (way less than twice our original goal), we'll be able to make six more episodes — and you can help decide whose stories we tell next!
STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT is the next major webseries from my company, Flying Saucer Media. I've worked for 25 years in media production. I was the head writer and producer of TechTV's "The Screen Savers"; editor-in-chief of the six-time Webby Award winning escapistmagazine.com; co-founder of Polygon.com; and creator Polygon's "Human Angle" webseries, short documentaries about people in video games.
STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT is picking up where Human Angle left off, with an entirely new 6-episode series chronicling the real human stories of video games. And to ensure that no one can pull the plug, call the shots or change the course, I'm asking for your help to fund this series.
Production of STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT has already begun. I've spent my own money shooting the first two episodes of this series. And pre-production has begun on several additional episodes. 
STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT will be six episodes. We're asking for your help to raise $192,105. That's a very precise figure, and one we're confident in. We're experienced video professionals with over 25 years experience making high-quality video. We know how much it costs, how hidden costs can stack up, and how to avoid surprises up-front. We've provided a detailed breakdown of why we're asking for what we're asking below. I think after reading and hearing more about what we're trying to accomplish you'll agree we're aiming for a reasonable goal.
Each 7-10 minute episode of STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT tells a new story about an interesting, exceptional or revolutionary personality in the video game community. What is it like to be an indie developer working with a dozen other people around the world? What kind of child grows up raised by some of the most famous game developers in the world? How do you make a game better than your first game, when your first game was one of the best reviewed games out there? And what kind of person has millions of fans just for making videos on YouTube? STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT will answer all of these questions and more.
The first episode will publish the same day this Kickstarter closes, whether or not the series is funded. New episodes will then follow every month.
At Flying Saucer Media, we run very small crews. For STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT, we'll be working with freelance contributors for almost every shoot, but the core team will be:
Producing six, separate short documentary films covering subjects all over the world is no easy task. I know. I've done it before. I know exactly how much that will cost, how long it will take and (most importantly) how to do it right.
I'm asking for a lot of money. I'm asking for a lot of trust. I hope you agree that telling these amazing stories is worth a little of both.
Crew fees and travel are the biggest expenses. The second biggest expense is backer rewards, that's the stuff we're making and shipping to you for backing this project. I'm borrowing Robert Khoo's excellent analysis of how much that sort of thing costs. I also borrowed Robert's math on how much Kickstarter and credit card companies will charge me for the privilege of taking your money. It's a lot! 
Stage of Development is going to cost us $138,650 to produce (rounded to the nearest dollar). That includes crew fees, travel, contingency (in case something breaks) and fees for music composition and licensing.
Adding in the cost to produce the awesome backer rewards ($38,406.05) and the amount Kickstarter will charge to raise the remaining sum ($15,049.76) we get to $192,105.
Or put another way:
The portion of this chart that looks like Pac-Man is how much we need in order to produce Stage of Development.
The rest is how much we need to spend in order to raise the amount we need to produce Stage of Development.
The first episode of Stage of Development will be available to backers as a digital download the same day this Kickstarter closes. No excuses.
Episode 1: September 16 (The day this Kickstarter closes)
Episodes 2-6: One per month, every month. 
That's not bluster. The episode been shot and is currently in the final stages of post-production.
We are planning to publish additional episodes every 3-4 weeks. Right now we have all of the six episodes booked and scheduled for production and post-production.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The only serious risk is that someone's schedule might change, forcing us to adjust our production schedule, possibly costing us more or affecting the amount of time it will take to finish an episode.

This is the sort of thing where experience leads to a much lower risk. I've done this before. I've run into these issues. And I know how to work around them and plan a schedule and a budget keeping in mind that things may change.

Realistically, there's a 100% chance that something will happen differently than we've planned it. But there's a statistically zero chance that a disruption will be so severe that it will impact our schedule or budget so severely that we can't adjust. 

I don't want to say "never" but I've been managing schedules and budgets for decades. Both "Press Reset" and "Human Angle" came in on time and under budget. As has every production I've ever been a part of. If STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT were to run over budget or take longer than I expected, it would be the first.

campaign.story:
Several years ago I made it a goal to always carry a sketchbook. This lead to the creation of Sketch Wallet - a leather wallet that holds a sketchbook. It comes in black or chocolate brown leather with a matching sketchbook.
 If there is a combination of things you'd like, but don't see in the rewards, just do the math and give me a note explaining what you want. For example, if you'd like one sketchbook and a t-shirt, just select the t-shirt and then add $4 to your pledge for the sketchbook. 
 I've been using a prototype Sketch Wallet for two years and absolutely love it. I can't imagine not having one. It doesn't matter where I am, the doctor's office, a restaurant, or wherever. If I have a few moments I'll doodle a few sketches instead of surfing the net on my phone. I've come to cherish all these quirky little drawings and many of these raw ideas I've developed further into games I create for work and other projects. This has brought the joy of drawing back, and has helped me improve my skills.
The Sketch Wallet is very flat and is designed to maximize the area of a standard men's back pocket without feeling bulky or heavy.
Attention writers and note takers - now you have the option of lined paper! After the campaign you will receive an email survey and can pick blank sketch books or lined paper books.
We respect craftsmen everywhere, but I wanted to use local factories to ensure the best quality and ethics possible. Our wallets and sketchbooks are made in the USA.
 STRETCH GOALS!
UNLOCKED! If we hit $35,000 every reward level, small or large, gets a small metal page clip. 
UNLOCKED! If we hit $40,000 every wallet will come with a custom short *pencil perfectly sized to fit the pencil pocket. *Pencil design may change (still figuring out what type of pencil)
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I've tried to anticipate potential challenges with this project and have made every effort to overcome them. The factory and printers are already in place. The wallet dies and hot stamps have already been made. Not only have a few prototypes been made but I manufactured a small batch just to work out all the kinks in manufacturing before the Kickstarter campaign began. It's extremely expensive to manufacture a small batch, but I felt it was crucial to ironing out any kinks in the pipeline beforehand. While I don't have any leather product experience, I have, over the years, designed, manufactured, and shipped hundreds of products made of metal, plastic, and rubber. While I'm sure I can't foresee every potential problem, I will be very open about any challenges that may arise, and will communicate often with my backers.

We had everything that could be done beforehand ready to go and worked until very late last night (or early this morning) and will keep shipping like crazy until it's all done. It's a little bit of a process; I un-bag the wallet, add the sketchbook or notebook, add the other goodies in the box, give it a kiss, then tuck it nicely into the packaging. Then I print the label, double check the order, tape it up and add to the shipping pile.

Good morning everyone!
So the brown wallets have been slowly creeping across the US from the East Coast to the West Coast. I was hoping to have them by now but that's the story of this project :-( but I'm happy to watch them get closer and closer every day. They are due to arrive Monday and I'm arranging to have them held at the sorting facility so I can pick them up as early as possible and get them shipped out to you the same day. As you can see from the photo my house looks like a shipping wonderland. Notice all the boxes are assembled along the walls and are ready to ship. Saturday I will print all the labels so if you get a shipping notice it just means I printed your label. The US orders are going in priority flat rate boxes which deliver in 1,2, or 3 days. I've been tracking international packages and the delivery times are all over the place. Some countries have more reliable post then others. Sometimes they get stuck in customs and other times they skip right through. Anyway, I just wanted to keep you up to date on their progress. I have black wallets and both color sketchbooks on the shelf that are available to ship immediately at
